reviews.review_msg: I took this class with a perception in mind that it would be brutal, given the reviews here, but it turned out to be the opposite. Martin was accommodating when I asked for two extensions. The TA, Sara was super helpful and timely in email responses and helped me otherwise too. If you put in the work, this course will be enjoyable! :)
Crim 320 is not an easy class but Martin tries his best not to make it more painful than necessary. Try your best on the midterm and labs because the final is brutal. The TAs were amazing.

His workbook and textbook are entirely useless, as is attending lecture. The labs are easy enough if you attend tutorial, the TAs are awesome. Martin doesn't seem to want students to succeed, we are expected to read his mind for what he wants to see in lab write ups and we were not given nearly enough time for the midterm.

Seemed good at first, but his assignments give you zero direction and the corresponding textbook and workbook do no t help you to the extent needed to succeed. I didn't mind the way be taught but he would ramble in too much. The tests were terrible. Not enough time to complete with no option to look at the entire exam. Exams online and open book.

If you are good at teaching yourself you will do well in the course.  There is not enough time given for exams, both had the strongest weighted questions left to the end with no option of going back to previous questions.  Regardless, it is a simple stats course so if you do the work you will do well, the professor does not help in your learning.

The class content was hard but Martin just makes it worse. Extremely boring, uninteresting, and useless lectures. His textbook and instructions in the workbook for weekly assignments are unclear and confusing. The tests were extremely difficult with not enough time to even finish them. He is also extremely passive aggressive in emails.
textbook/workbook is a joke, full of spelling errors and very hard to follow along with, I recommend not taking this class with him if you have the chance to

Listen to everyone, do not take his class if you have other options. You have to buy his books on a platform that doesn't even support zooming in, lectures are sorta political, and the tutorials (at the time) are pretty much a catch up block. Weekly lab's don't have a clear criteria as well as the tests. Don't bother with his class
Very disrespectful to students with an ego. And very unapologetic for anything.

Meh is the experience with this prof. he's not bad, but TA Sara is really helpful. What made me mad was how he promised to curve our grades but didn't, and as per his own grading scale. i should have gotten an A-, but ended with a B. Whatever.

He changes his course this semester to make it better for students and while this helped the overall grade of the students he would not round at the end of the semester if you were on the cusp of the next letter grade because we reached the max 70% of students have a B- or higher. he also said he would mark on the curve but then he did not.
Not a bad teacher, just a hard class

Class was blended but we only ended up having 3 IRL lectures because of how he scheduled the course (eg he cancelled class to attend conferences). He was engaging in person but not online. The tests were tough but he scaled the end grades to make it fair. Didn't need to attend labs because the workbook he wrote gave step-by-step instructions.

If you scroll back on this prof rating you can see that in the past, he had positive reviews. I mean this wholeheartedly when I say something serious must have happened in his life for someone to turn so bitter and disrespectful. Online tests had problems and he said "not my problem, its IT" and would not help students/ got mad at US!?? AVOID HIM!

The most difficult prof taken at SFU. He is rude, does not accommodate, and is disrespectful. I am surprised in why the crim faculty has allowed him to continue teaching this course when a majority of students are struggling every term. I have felt disrespected and ashamed and does not support his students in doing well. Avoid at all costs.

literally the WORST prof Ive taken and this is my last semester... He is totally disengaged from his student. I really hope he does some work to reengage with his work and students because I think everyone struggled this term under his instruction, or lack there of. He seems like a good guy- idk why he would treat his students so poorly

Now that the term is over, I would like to say Martin is the worst prof at SFU. Class average for the exam was 50% and he takes no responsibility. He does not believe that his way of writing exams is wrong, does not take student feedback, and does nothing to change. If you dont like suffering take a different prof. Thank me later.
DONT TAKE A CLASS WITH MARTIN. I can honestly say hes the worst prof in crim at sfu

First time I've had to drop a course this far into the semester. The workbook, written by the prof, was so informally written that it was impossible to follow along with. It felt like there were more jokes incorporated than actual course content. Also, he uses a different statistical program than the TAs, so it was more difficult than it had to be.

Confirmed why I worried taking this class with this professor based on experiences heard from others. For one of his exams he did not take any responsibility over his own mistakes (iykyk) leading to many students to be negatively impacted by it. Overall: difficult class/content, not enough room to improve, and no compassion from the professor.
Good luck to everyone taking this class...imagine taking a class with a prof who is proud that his class average is 50ish% Dont take this class alone! Suffer together!

Do not take 320 with Martin...he seemed to have little investment in his students or the class. 

The second online test had a malfunction and there was no one (no TA or Martin) available during the test to help. Little was done to make up for their mistake despite them wasting our time
Good luck
Definitely have to put in the work to do well. Course content basically becomes statistics in the second half of the course with lots of graphs and variables.

I would advise potential students to seek alternative options if they want an effective and engaging learning experience. Professor Andresen does not provide the support or quality of education one should expect from a university instructor.
Midterm average was 50%.

the course was blended, but we had 3 IRL lectures. Tutorial participation is 1/4 grade but we've had 2 tutorials because of the strike and the last 3 are for presentations. The midterm was way too long for the short amount of time he gave. His slides are dry and useless. At least he seems like an approachable person.
the worst
Have to read two chapters each week like 40-60 pages
talks about random things off-topic in lecture and says to watch his recorded lectures that he filmed years ago to learn the material

Terrible prof, might be the worst prof i have ever had. Very unprofessional, rude to students, and does not inform students of anything. The test is unreasonably difficult, and he does not inform students of what to expect with the exam. Do not take a course with him if you want a good semester he will ruin it.
unfair exams

Do not take courses with Martin Andresen. He puts in no effort to teaching the class, our course alternated between online and in person lectures, but for the online weeks he just posted his lectures from 3 years ago. He makes you buy the textbook that he wrote, which has a lot of repeating points like someone trying to fill the word count. Avoid.
The most unprofessional prof at SFU. Don't trust his high review, only if you're taking an introduction class with him. DON'T TAKE UPPER DIVISION COURSES WITH MARTIN

Midterm is 6-7 pages writing (19 paragraphs) + 10 multiple choice + 10 true/false in 90 minutes. This is the first exam I've taken that I genuinely could not finish the exam because of running out of time. 
He also does not send emails out ever, even during the strike. Literally does not care.

Dr Andresen is a great prof, his lectures are super clear and easy to follow. Even though I took CRIM101 as an intersession course, so there was a lot of required reading in a really short time, his lectures and tutorial discussion questions made it simple to understand what I needed to know to pass his exams

I loved this class, the professor and the TAs were great. A lot of dad jokes were made. The course material was really interesting to me, but there was quite a bit of reading involved. Attendance is mandatory for tutorials, not for lectures.

The grading for lab assignment is very unclear and lack detailed instruction on what you need to get all the marks, so you are always losing marks no matter what. He should really update his workbook that you need for your lab assignments (you have to pay for it). You shouldn't skip the tutorial, as the workbook can be useless for most terms.

Martin is a nice guy and very knowledgeable about statistics however, his classes were hard to sit through and his slides were very bland. His midterm was fair but his final was harsh and heavily focused on labs. Be ready to put in the work for this class and try not to fall asleep during lectures.

He is a nice guy but his lectures were just a summary of his textbook so they were not useful. Labs were only helpful if you had a good TA. The averages for the exams are 50% and currently failing our final. The exam questions are very hard and focus on definitions, lab material and multiple choice.

Martin himself seems like a nice guy, however, he makes his exams unreasonably hard. During the first lecture he specified that the average for exams is 50%. If that many students are barely passing the exam, then maybe the problem is your teaching style and not the course content. I got an A+ in previous Statistics courses, barely passing now.

Martin is a nice enough guy and likes to joke around. His lectures were extremely bland and consisted exclusively of excerpts from his textbook (brutal read).
He seems to be knowledgable on statistical testing, but was not successful in teaching the content during lecture. Lecture and teaching style not conducive to understanding statistics.

Martin was an okay prof for this course. One aspect I didnt like was how bland and dull his lecture slides were. The entire course had to be taught straight from the textbook and nothing from the slides. My only recommendation would be that the slides need to be much better. Overall, martins course was okay, just focus on chapter questions

Martin was a decent prof. I did find that his course structure can be confusing at times based on what he asks for on assignments. Nonetheless, he always respond fast to emails, which is good. His lecture slides were helpful and can contribute to most of what you need to know. Exam question can straight from textbook.

He is definitely one of the better profs at this school. The assignments were all clustered at the end of the term, so just be sure to plan things out ahead of time. For the exams, the written questions are right out of the chapter review questions, so study those. Overall, I would rate the difficulty as medium-high. Pretty solid elective to choose

The prof is a nice guy and you can tell he cares, my complaint is the class itself. All of the assignments are clustered around the final 2-3 weeks of class rather than being spread out in the semester. The readings are long and dry; LOTS of reading. Unless you love env crim, I do not recommend taking this class, it will be rough. Overall, avoid

Martin was great, his lectures were complementary to the textbook, if there is something in the textbook you don't understand Martin will explain extremely well in lecture. His tests are extremely fair the questions are the same from his textbook, and the same ones that are answered and discussed in tutorials, so participate and pay attention. GR8

This is considered a dry class and a lot of students didn't do well so it was actually the first time I had a grade curved. He is very knowledgeable and knows what he's doing as he actually conducts research. Super funny and always told us hilarious stories to make this class bearable. The class itself is hard if you don't work hard for it.
One of the greatest professor at Sfu. He is really helpful. Taking his Crim 320 class is highly recommended.

Martin is a great guy, relaxed and funny! Class was very straight-forward. All organized and clearly laid out, easy A if you participate & do your readings! He lets class discussion steer the lecture, and really wants to help you. Material not THAT interesting, but he tries to make it better with humour! VERY easy paper and fair midterm!

This class was average. The grading is completely arbitrary and this is evident by the range/distribution of grades. Participation is mandatory yet he dominates conversations and does not facilitate student discussion. He compensates for his arbitrary grading by marking "hard" on participation. He needs to adjust his teaching styles.

Martin is a nice, approachable and funny professor. i wouldn't recommend taking crim352 because this class is all about THEORY! its a repetition of crim 300 but easier. the material is dry, although Martin tries to make it interesting. participation is a big chunk of your grade and Martin marks hard on participation. marks easier on everything else
Take this class with him!!! Memorizing important info from the textbook is enough to score an A.
Material is dry but this prof made it better to comprehend. Midterm and Final are fairly easy, all multiple choice and T/F. Written assignments were simple too.
Very interesting prof. I like him!
Nice prof

An amazing prof. No PPT. He just sits there and talks while telling jokes nad using real life examples. It works out really well. His exams were fair since he gave us a bank of 50 questions in advance and 15 were chosen. One textbook was not used at all while the other was used for the paper or assignment.

Awesome guy, cant ask for more out of him. His lectures are different, no PP, but it causes you to listen more. His jokes are hilarious, along with his real life examples. Very knowledgeable. Recommend taking his class for Environmental Crim. One of my favorite profs at SFU for sure.

Very pleasant and knowledgeable guy.  Few too many repeated lame jokes, but overall decent and fair.  Just make sure you read the textbook definitions for the exam, not just his list.  Course is super-easy GPA-booster.

Probably one of the smartest men I've ever met - witty, engaging, amazing sense of the ironic. Oh, and did I say smart?  Also so cute to watch in his nerdy, awkward way. Could make reading the telephone directory fascinating.
Funny, insightful and incredibly interesting - of course you have to have an IQ that matches his to get all the jokes though.

Lectures are really boring and long. His textbook is super thick and not that good either. He is okay if you try to get on his side and participate in tutorials, but the lecture material was really dry. His lecture notes are like minimum of 12 pages long of full text per week!

Martin is an excellent teacher! He is a very straight forward guy, and his marking is very fair. Participate in seminar and you will honestly feel that you are getting your money's worth. He is a very approachable and interesting guy.

Martin is such a great professor. He truly cares about his students and is passionate about what he does. Unlike a lot of classes, you actually learn a lot in his seminars and makes you think. His marking is extremely fair and he gives you his notes after lecture to study from for the midterm. And did I mention no final? =D
amazing, knows his stuff. Totally fun class to attend
Great prof, interesting lectures. very helpful. study his notes for exam, no txt book needed.

loved his class, he's really funny, and he goes off on tangents, but it's a good thing becuz that makes the 930am class more barrable and less likely to fall asleep. the format of the class is really great! totally recommend taking class with him :)
great class, learned a lot about environmental criminology from someone who obviously enjoys the material.
